text: The individual racks get assembled with the machines/chips in the rack cabled together, so then you just have to cross connect the racks.  You still want individual trays of machines/tpus to be individually replaceable/serviceable, though, so making much larger non-separable units doesn't necessarily make sense.

@acnithin @GeminiApp Nice!

@_profbadtrip @TheXeophon @anpaure I was responding to your statement above that compute and energy usage are scaling at the same rate, which is clearly not true. 

https://t.co/Sgod4LgK34

Compute performance is scaling considerably faster than energy usage due to computer architecture and fabrication process improvements.  I asked Gemini to summarize for Nvidia GPUs, and you see a 12.8X improvement in fp16 perf over 4 generations with only 3x-4x energy increase.  And if you use fp8, it's 25.6x in b200 over the fp16 in p100.

text: @dhamijaabhi @Waymo Hard to control for that exactly.  We know it for the Waymo vehicles but not for the human drivers.  The baseline is controlled to be human drivers in the same zip codes as Waymo operates, which controls for local driving conditions, weather, etc. per vehicle mile traveled. https://t.co/83hODEoUFx

@fizzbhau @Waymo See here for the baseline (roughly, human drivers in the same zip codes as Waymo operates, normalized for vehicle miles traveled using various state and local data sources). https://t.co/8uDmp1SObS

@edleeprof @Waymo The study is comparing Waymo autonomous driving to human drivers in the same zip codes where Waymo operates (which helps ensure comparison of similar driving conditions) per mile traveled, estimating vehicle miles traveled using various city and state data sources. https://t.co/LD0jEi990n
You should follow our new @googleaidevs account for the latest news. â¬‡ï¸

After 25.3 million autonomous miles driven, @Waymo vehicles have an 88% reduction in property damage claims and a 92% reduction in bodily injury claims compared to human drivers per mile driven. ğŸš– https://t.co/7ebvsuI7Tw

text:
Oh.

"However, despite covering this immense distance, his world record attempt was not officially recognized because he fell just 80 meters short of the finish line. In the sport of slacklining, the rules stipulate that a record must be completed without falling to be validated."
This seems like it was super windy.  I didn't have a fantastic sense of balance, so when I see this, I just marvel at how it is possible to slackline 3.6km in gusty winds.
We've focused on improving coding ability for Gemini models.  It looks like it's working (and the long context capabilities are very useful in real world coding settings).
This is a hoot!  Gemini fills in steps 1.25, 1.5, and 1.75 for the journey from step 1 (one circle)  to step 2 (complete owl).

I'm looking forward to chatting with people at NeurIPS at the Google booth (center of Hall A downstairs) at noon today, with some of my awesome Gemini colleagues:

@sterlingshrey @a__tomala @mirrokni @WonderMicky @iamandrewdai @dtarlow2 @Skiminok

Trillium (TPU v6e) is now generally available for Google Cloud customers.  It's quite a high performance system and we've been using it internally for various things in Gemini and are quite happy with it!

Gemini 2.0 Flash is here! ğŸŠ

We're quite excited about this model.  It's better than Gemini 1.5 Pro on most benchmarks, but comparable in speed and latency to Gemini 1.5 Flash.  It has multilingual native audio output, native image output, native tool use, and a new multimodal live API for streaming audio and video.  It's an awesome model for building all kinds of interesting agents, and we're excited to see what developers do with it!

Credit to the whole Gemini team: I'm so proud of everyone's work here!

text:
@epistemic13 Classical numerical weather prediction uses physics-based simulations, while the AI-based approaches learn from observational data.

https://t.co/JxuNx3nC2R

@_Trydml Yes, exactly. 

A similar graph of quality versus latency would look pretty good for Gemini, I suspect.
@andromeda74356 We haven't announced prices for any of the exp models (and may not launch exactly these models as paid models), so the original poster made some assumptions.

Look at the Pareto frontier of the red Gemini/Gemma dots.  At a given price point, the Gemini model is higher quality.  At a given quality (ELO score), the Gemini/Gemma model is the cheapest alternative.

It's been really awesome to watch the progression of improvements in AI weather prediction.  5-6 years ago, AI models started to be better than classic methods out to about 6-8 hours.  Then it became 2-3 days, and now, AI methods are state of the art out to 15 days (+ way more efficient!)
@roydanroy Instead of a race, I prefer to think of it as continual progress for AI, and I don't think this is the end, but rather a nice kilometerstone along the way.

I'm just bewildered by some of the discussion in these comments.  Language is how we communicate, and words have meaning that help us understand each other.  So when people claim that you can't have equity and fairness, because they are opposites, when they are literally synonyms, something has gone awry.
@_arohan_ Rohan, thanks for all your work over the years.  I have enjoyed working with you, and I'll miss our chats!

text: Equity to me means making fair decisions.  As an example, consider a hospital emergency room triage process.  An equitable process would take care of the most critically urgent cases and devote more healthcare system resources to treat them.  An equality policy would treat people in the order they arrived, and use equal resources on each person.  In some settings, equity makes a lot more sense than equality.
@Dieter75 @pmarca Equity is merely the quality of being fair and impartial.  I'm not sure why you have such a negative reaction to these ideals. https://t.co/M3xxAj9sIr
@prince_of_fakes @pmarca Ahh, yes.  Being fair and impartial is nonsense? https://t.co/ko3FvKenD4
@devilscompiler @pmarca Equity is the quality of being fair and impartial.  Are you saying that's not consistent with American values? https://t.co/969T92xmft
@JosephJacks_ @pmarca Why would I want to embrace inequity (the "lack of fairness or justice")?  Why would your want to embrace that? https://t.co/dGvoUp59Gr
@rootsaandwings @pmarca Since they're practically synonyms, it's hard to have one without the other. https://t.co/MWXSQwoLaX
@qxvnxb @pmarca I'm not sure how you got the impression that fairness and equity are opposites.  I view them as nearly synonymous. https://t.co/Gmv6JNMaWi

@pmarca The way I was raised, fairness and equity were traits to be aspired to and were held up as quintessential American values.  I don't see how you got the take you did from reading that section of the paper.

Shaping AI's Impact on Billions of Lives
Iâ€™m delighted to have collaborated with an awesome set of co-authors ğŸŠ on this paper that offers a blueprint of actions that can be taken by practitioners, policymakers, and other stakeholders to maximize the upsides of AI and minimize its downsides.  We include 18 concrete milestones to guide AI research and development in that direction.

Authors: Mariano-Florentino CuÃ©llar, myself (@JeffDean), @FinaleDoshi, John Hennessy, @andykonwinski, @sanmikoyejo, @tamati_biskit, @2plus2make5, and David Patterson.

Arxiv link: https://t.co/sBRkdIGo2x

One page Economist OpEd â€œAn agenda to maximise AIâ€™s benefits and minimise harmsâ€ by Dave: https://t.co/k7jo2d5UvA

Abstract
Artificial Intelligence (AI), like any transformative technology, has the potential to be a double-edged sword, leading either toward significant advancements or detrimental outcomes for society as a whole. As is often the case when it comes to widely-used technologies in market economies (e.g., cars and semiconductor chips), commercial interest tends to be the predominant guiding factor. The AI community is at risk of becoming polarized to either take a laissez-faire attitude toward AI development, or to call for government overregulation. Between these two poles we argue for the community of AI practitioners to consciously and proactively work for the common good. This paper offers a blueprint for a new type of innovation infrastructure including 18 concrete milestones to guide AI research in that direction. Our view is that we are still in the early days of practical AI, and focused efforts by practitioners, policymakers, and other stakeholders can still maximize the upsides of AI and minimize its downsides.

We talked to luminaries such as recent Nobelist John Jumper on science, President @BarackObama on governance, former UN Ambassador and former National Security Advisor Susan Rice @AmbassadorRice on security, philanthropist @EricSchmidt on several topics, and science fiction novelist @nealstephenson on entertainment. This ongoing dialogue and collaborative effort has produced a comprehensive, realistic view of what the actual impact of AI could be, from a diverse assembly of thinkers with deep understanding of this technology and these domains. From these exchanges, five recurring guidelines emerged, which form the cornerstone of a framework for beginning to harness AI in service of the public good. They not only guide our efforts in discovery but also shape our approach to deploying this transformative technology responsibly and ethically.

https://t.co/EnGEIqiuyI

This is pretty sad.  Being about to be informed enough to make reasonable estimates of things in the world is an important aspect of overall understanding.  The respondents to this survey think the population of NYC is 100M people (Muslim + Jewish %ages are off by 27X & 15X, as well).

Our paper was originally published in Nature (https://t.co/QmJA56ZcZ6).  Some in the EDA community questioned its results (presumably based on flawed efforts like the Cheng et al. paper), and Nature initiated a second peer review process, which resulted in our results being completely upheld.

As an update, Shankar Krishnamoorthy, Head of Technology & Product Development at @Synopsys, reached out to me to say "Regarding the CACM article that Igor Markov's comments and writings do not represent Synopsys views or opinions in any way. Synopsys is also aligned with you on the potential of Reinforcement Learning AI for chip design as evidenced by strong customer adoption of our https://t.co/jP3KQgBxlX suite of products."

text:
@truboparubok @y0b1byte @annadgoldie @Azaliamirh Link in tweet below along with more context

https://t.co/331FuefpLG

There has been unfounded skepticism in the EDA community about whether our AlphaChip method works as claimed in our Nature paper.  @annadgoldie, @Azaliamirh, and I wrote a technical response highlighting these issues:

That Chip Has Sailed: A Critique of Unfounded Skepticism Around AI for Chip Design
https://t.co/ABB3cLnBjL

Much of this unfounded skepticism is driven by a deeply flawed non-peer-reviewed publication by Cheng et al. (https://t.co/BMD7VpndzM) that claimed to replicate our approach but failed to follow our methodology in major ways.  In particular the authors did no pre-training (despite pre-training being mentioned 37 times in our Nature article), robbing our learning-based method of its ability to learn from other chip designs, then used 20X less compute and did not train to convergence, preventing our method from fully learning even on the chip design being placed.  By analogy, this would be like evaluating a version of AlphaGo that had never seen a game of Go before (instead of being pre-trained on millions of games), and then concluding that AlphaGo is not very good at Go.

We also respond to Igor Markovâ€™s â€œmeta-analysisâ€ published in the Nov 2024 issue of CACM.  In Markovâ€™s paper (published without disclosing that Markov is a high-level employee at Synopsys, which makes commercial software that competes with our open-source release of AlphaChip), Markov â€œmeta-analyzesâ€ the flawed Cheng et al. paper and another unpublished anonymous PDF (https://t.co/i1mLzVcwTr) with no listed authors on which Markov is a shadow co-author (effectively regurgitating his own unpublished arguments as if they were independent).  The Markov article makes veiled accusations, all completely baseless and already found to be without merit by Nature. I am surprised @Synopsys wants to be associated with this, and I am surprised @CACMmag  saw fit to publish these sorts of allegations with no evidence, nor any technical data other than two flawed, non-peer reviewed articles.

Read @annadgoldie's post below for more info. â¬‡ï¸

text:
@ogawa_tter The Markov CACM article is based on two highly flawed, non-peer-reviewed papers.

https://t.co/Ia6Pd2I5gU

@tomaxwell @annadgoldie @Azaliamirh My co-authors went to work for a different company for a year and then we were able to convince them to come back (yay!).  This isn't all that unusual in Silicon Valley.

There has been unfounded skepticism in the EDA community about whether our AlphaChip method works as claimed in our Nature paper.  @annadgoldie, @Azaliamirh, and I wrote a technical response highlighting these issues:

That Chip Has Sailed: A Critique of Unfounded Skepticism Around AI for Chip Design
https://t.co/ABB3cLnBjL

Much of this unfounded skepticism is driven by a deeply flawed non-peer-reviewed publication by Cheng et al. (https://t.co/BMD7VpndzM) that claimed to replicate our approach but failed to follow our methodology in major ways.  In particular the authors did no pre-training (despite pre-training being mentioned 37 times in our Nature article), robbing our learning-based method of its ability to learn from other chip designs, then used 20X less compute and did not train to convergence, preventing our method from fully learning even on the chip design being placed.  By analogy, this would be like evaluating a version of AlphaGo that had never seen a game of Go before (instead of being pre-trained on millions of games), and then concluding that AlphaGo is not very good at Go.

We also respond to Igor Markovâ€™s â€œmeta-analysisâ€ published in the Nov 2024 issue of CACM.  In Markovâ€™s paper (published without disclosing that Markov is a high-level employee at Synopsys, which makes commercial software that competes with our open-source release of AlphaChip), Markov â€œmeta-analyzesâ€ the flawed Cheng et al. paper and another unpublished anonymous PDF (https://t.co/MJgEwSM4wS) with no listed authors on which Markov is a shadow co-author (effectively regurgitating his own unpublished arguments as if they were independent).  The Markov article makes veiled accusations, all completely baseless and already found to be without merit by Nature.  I am surprised @Synopsys wants to be associated with this, and I am surprised @CACMmag  saw fit to publish these sorts of allegations with no evidence, nor any technical data other than two flawed, non-peer reviewed articles.

Read @annadgoldie's post below for more info. â¬‡ï¸

I didn't come up with the name.  I called it 'CompactFloat', if I remember correctly.  The bfloat16 moniker was given later by some folks in our early TPUv2 hardware team when they were exploring 16-bit floating point formats, to distinguish it from the IEEE fp16 format (that turned out to not be a good choice for neural net training).

text:
Some intuition, some luck.  We already knew that neural net training was very tolerant of noise (we were doing asynchronous updates from dozens of replicas to train large models, which added lots of noise to the updates).  Noise is ~ the least important bits, so I said "well, I'd rather lose almost all the mantissa bits before I lose any exponent bits".  Dropping 16 mantissa bits turned out to be a sweet spot and was also convenient to do in software (send 2 bytes, skip 2 bytes, send 2 bytes, skip 2 bytes, ...).

The hardware implementations in the TPUv2 came later, and there was careful simulation/sweeping of training workloads on # of exponent bits/# of mantissa bits to decide on the 16-bit float format, which ended up with the original "bfloat16: drop 16 bits of mantissa and use 8 exponent bits and 7 mantissa bits" being the best choice.

@einsums @doctorow Gas generators aren't the only option.  Presumably wind, solar or nuclear could be great options to power such a cluster.  And taxes with the appropriate pricing of negative externalities might help shift the choice towards something with a cleaner firm of energy.

@einsums @doctorow We should have taxed carbon emissions two decades ago.  That would have accelerated the shift we're seeing now towards renewables.

Taxing negative externalities can be pretty effective.  Also useful for other things: see congestion pricing in some cities.

I probably pay ~50% tax rate between state and federal taxes.  70% wouldn't change my lifestyle significantly (I'd still be able to buy new high end running shoes whenever there was a hint of my current pair wearing out).  Effective government spending is essential for society to truly benefit, though, I agree.

The linked article by @doctorow is full of early results of various states' new taxes aimed at extremely wealthy individuals.  Also, it reminds us that top tax rates in the US were 94% and 70%, during unprecedented economic expansion in the US. https://t.co/JQ8zuoxWPj

@strubell Fair enough.  Deleting that comment.

In July 2024, we released emissions estimates for pre-training the Gemma 2 model series (2B, 9B, and 27B parameter models, so ~12X, ~43X, and ~128X larger than the 213M parameter models you were looking at, and respectively trained on 2T, 8T, and 13T tokens of data).

We estimate that pre-training for all three of these much larger models produced ~1248t CO2e, or 4.4X more than the off-by-orders-of-magnitude estimate of 284t from Strubell et al. for training a 213m parameter models).  And yes, training much larger models overtrained significantly more do indeed produce more emissions than tiny models (unless done in a 100% renewable energy facility like our Montreal datacenters).   These models were also open-sourced so that others were free to use them or fine-tune them for their own purposes (perhaps reducing overall emissions versus everyone training their own models).

See: https://t.co/DjhKh7deUR

It sure seems to say that to an awful lot of people (all the "lifetime of five cars" stuff).  Perhaps more importantly, in 2022, in https://t.co/zpX91tTFDA, a paper you co-authored, the self-citation description of your own 2019 work says "Attention was first drawn to the environmental impact of AI research by the seminal work of Strubell et al. [42], which quantified the emissions produced by training a Transformer model with Neural Architecture search, finding it to be comparable to the lifetime carbon emissions of five cars."

So, in your own words (and after learning of the error in the computation which you then knew to be incorrect), the original paper does make exactly that claim.

https://t.co/ukipQsswjn that I helped co-author has quite a lot of details for models from Google and other models.  It's actually quite a lot of work to do this.

Table 4 in the paper has information about the training power, emissions, etc. for the Evolved Transformer NAS, as well as training runs for T5, Meena, the 600B parameter GShard model, the Switch Transformer, and GPT-3 (from OpenAI).

Table 3 has info about average power consumption for various AI accelerators in Google datacenters.

Table 1 has info about various configurations of training Transformer (big) and the Evolved Transformer (medium) configurations on different kinds of hardware.

text: @strubell I don't recall anything of the sort.  I might have said that honest mistakes happen and that correcting the original paper would be the right thing for science and would actually improve your research reputation, which I still believe.

@abbeyResearches @boazbaraktcs Indeed, and we invited @strubell to be a co-author with us on https://t.co/6n59C2mAkF that corrects the calculations done in the original paper, but she declined.

It gives people a very incorrect view of the actual emissions costs of training language models.  So people think "If a tiny model generated that much emissions, larger models must be thousands of times more than this" when in actual fact, because of the errors, this isn't the case.

Not sure what the more recent and much larger Gemma-2 models (2B, 9B and 27B parameters) have to do with this.  The main issue is that your paper claimed that training a small 213m parameter transformer model emitted 284t CO2e, when in fact the correct number is 0.087 t CO2e, or 0.0024t CO2e if you use the open-sourced results of the Evolved Transformer neural architecture search in a reasonably efficient and clean energy setting.  I tend to think errors of 3261X to ~120,000X in a prominently visible number do indeed give people a wrong impression of the true emissions costs.

text:
@strubell A bit more info here: 

https://t.co/RQjqjCfPS0

I'm just looking at the timeline:

2019 - honest mistakes in Strubell et al. paper (https://t.co/v1wDySBZiQ) in assessing emissions cost of Evolved Transformer neutral architecture search (off by 88X:  19X from not understanding the search process done in the actual So et al. work, 5X for not accounting for the environment/committing hardware in which the comparison was run, much of which was admittedly difficult to assess from outside Google).  The paper also implies this is an every problem cost and that you ran and measured the emissions of the neural architecture search, when in fact you had just incorrectly estimated the cost and not actually run any sort of neural architecture search.

2021 - discussions  between myself, David Patterson and @strubell and others about these errors about why the 626,155 lbs CO2e number in  https://t.co/v1wDySBZiQ was incorrect (due to the reasons above)

If I recall, our discussion in 2021 ended with us saying that we would proceed with publishing https://t.co/ukipQsswjn which has an analysis of the issues described above, even if you didn't want to join as a co-author (that's not discrediting you as a researcher, but just a statement that we were going to go ahead and publish the arxiv paper discussing the errors in https://t.co/v1wDySBZiQ: that's how science works).  I also suggested that updating your ACL paper in light of the errors would be a good thing, which you refused, saying it wasn't an egregious error (we disagree on that, but fine)

2022 - after learning about these errors, you are a co-author on a new paper https://t.co/UwdmY25k3g that uses the now-known-to-be-incorrect data in new work.  See the first sentences of related work section of that paper and tweet below.  Given that you knew the "lifetime of five cars/626,155 lbs CO2e" number was bogus at that point, that doesn't seem reasonable to me.  Maybe there's an explanation for this, but given the timeline and the fact that our conversations the year before clearly discussed the errors with you, I'm struggling to see it.

I find the continued use of data now known to be drastically wrong in new papers by the same author especially troubling, I will admit.

Not to mention that the actual emissions cost of the neural architecture search for the Evolved Transformer, which isn't even about training an NLP model, turned out to be overstated by 88X.

text:
Knowing that Neural Architecture Search is a one-time cost per problem domain, not a per-problem cost was definitely widespread knowledge in the ML community at the time of the publication.  So that 3261X error was avoidable by simply using their own actual measurements of the cost of training an LLM (e.g. the row above in Table 1 of their paper) and not counting a one-time cost done in an efficient data center as an every problem cost.  It's a bit like saying "I'm going to count the cost of building the factory for every item built in the factory".

The NAS emissions estimate was off by 88X from the actual NAS emissions.  19X of this error was avoidable at the time of publication by carefully reading the already published So et al. paper they were referencing (see Appendix C in https://t.co/MPXQivSvTh for discussion of the error).

The additional 5X error due to knowledge about where the computation ran in Google and the energy efficiency of those devices (e.g. Appendix D in https://t.co/MPXQivSvTh) would indeed have been harder to assess using public information available at the time, but it would have been easy to use Google's average PUE instead of the average U.S. datacenter's PUE, since it was known that the computation ran within Google datacenters on TPU v2s (per So et al.).  That's a ~1.4X difference in actual emissions that would have been easy to account for based on data available at the time in https://t.co/DxSwrOEawV.

text: I guess this is where we disagree about whether an error of 3261X in estimating the cost of training a language model, or conflating a completely different one-time task to perform a neural architecture search (and overestimating that cost by 88X) to find more energy efficient models and calling that the every-time cost of training a language model of the scale you were examining counts as egregious mistakes or not.  The information needed to avoid these mistakes was available at the time your paper was published (it wasn't new information that came to light post publication).

I'm absolutely not suggesting you retract the paper.  I think it's a very good paper in many ways and got people thinking about these issues, which is quite valuable.  I just think updating the paper with correct information seems very valuable for the community, since the information from the flawed calculations keeps coming into discussions (e.g. see the start of this thread).  Certainly updating the Arxiv version should be very easy.

@infrecursion1 @SashaMTL @GaryMarcus @bate5a55 @strubell I'd prefer if we kept the discussion around the actual topic of environmental impacts of AI.  Please don't introduce incivility into a civilized discussion. ğŸ™

I'm all for that.  However that single number is still clouding people's assessment of the environmental costs (e.g. see how this thread started), and @strubell has flatly refused to amend the Arxiv or ACL paper with correct data, and has even co-authored papers after knowing about these errors (which we informed her of as part of our discussions in our writing of the 2021 paper https://t.co/ukipQsswjn).  To them further spread this erroneous information (e.g. the first sentence of the related work section of the 2022 work in https://t.co/zpX91tTFDA, which reiterates the wildly inaccurate "lifetime of five cars" meme) after being informed about the incorrect numbers is not honest and shouldn't be how science or transparency is done.

I think correcting the honest mistake but ultimately incorrect data in "Energy and Policy Considerations for Deep Learning in NLP" (https://t.co/v1wDySBZiQ) would be a good step towards more transparency, as you advocate, and then not publishing additional papers that knowingly use the incorrect data would be even better.

Until that happens, I'll continue to draw attention to the incorrect data as part of the broader discussion of transparency of environmental impacts.

Did you get this number from Strubell et. al?  Because that number was a very flawed estimate that turned out to be off by 88X, and the paper also portrayed it as an every time cost when in fact it was a one time cost. It's a good question.  In this case, we had already open sourced the code in 2022 (as a companion to the 2021 Nature paper), but we'd observed that it wasn't very easy for some in the community to take advantage of that because they had to find interesting blocks to pre-train on their own and then do the pre-training step.  Motivated organizations that already had lots of chip designs in house could clearly do this, but by releasing the pre-trained checkpoint, we make it easier for people/organizations without ready access to chip design blocks to use the technique via the open source repository+pre-trained checkpoint.
@Rybchuk @ylecun @deliprao @karpathy @AndrewYNg But it both supported and used backprop, as it said right in the paper.

Welcome, AlphaChip!

Today, we are sharing some exciting updates on our work published in @Nature in 2021 on using reinforcement learning for ASIC chip floorplanning and layout.  Weâ€™re also naming this work AlphaChip.

Since we first published this work, our use of this approach internally has grown significantly.  It has now been used for multiple generations of TPU chips (TPU v5e, TPU v5p, and Trillium), with AlphaChip placing an increasing number of blocks and with larger wirelength reductions vs. human experts from generation to generation:

AlphaChip has also been used with excellent results for other chips across Alphabet, including Googleâ€™s Axion chip, an Arm-based general-purpose data center CPU.

In 2022, as a companion to the Nature paper, we open-sourced the code for the AlphaChip algorithms described in the Nature paper (see link below).  Since then, external researchers could use this repository to pre-train on a variety of chip blocks and then apply the pre-trained model to new blocks, as was done and described in our original paper.

Today weâ€™re also releasing a pre-trained AlphaChip checkpoint for the open source release that makes it easier for external users to get started using AlphaChip for their own chip designs.

Original Nature paper w/ wonderful joint first authors @Azaliamirh + @annadgoldie, and @mnyazgan, @joesmemory, @ESonghori, @ShenWangURC, @xylophi, @efjohnson, @pathomkar, @Azade_na, @PakJiwoo, Andy Tong, @kavyasrinivas23, @willhang_, @emretuncer, @quocleix, @JamesLaudon, @rh00, Roger Carpenter, and myself):
https://t.co/QmJA56ZKOE   (PDF: https://t.co/HP7y1LhAh4)

Todayâ€™s Addendum to the paper published in Nature: https://t.co/BuGacrq57J (same authors)

AlphaChip blog post: https://t.co/oLBq1J8oXj

Open source release: https://t.co/cW1YMSHI57

Pre-trained checkpoint: https://t.co/iXtLqEjsH3

Three things we have observed in the external community are described in the Nature Addendum: (1) not doing any pre-training (circumventing the learning aspects of our method by removing its ability to learn from prior experience) (2) not training to convergence (standard practice in ML methods), and (3) using fewer computational resources than described in our Nature paper (using fewer resources is likely to harm performance, or require running for considerably longer to achieve the same performance).

Pre-training the model for it to learn the craft of chip layout and to be able to generalize to new designs is an important part of our method.  The pre-training process requires some effort to perform, since one has to find representative blocks and then run a lengthy computational process to pre-train the model to be good at placing those blocks.  To avoid external users having to perform this process and make it easier for the external community to use AlphaChip, today we are releasing an AlphaChip model checkpoint pre-trained on 20 TPU blocks.  This will enable users to get good zero-shot performance and faster convergence for novel blocks right out of the box.  (For best results, however, we continue to recommend that developers pre-train on their own in-distribution blocks, and we provide a tutorial on how to perform pre-training with our open-source repository: see the Addendum).

Many organizations have used AlphaChip as a building block for their own chip design efforts.  For example, MediaTek, one of the top chip design companies in the world, extended AlphaChip to accelerate development of their most advanced chips (e.g. the Dimensity Flagship 5G used in Samsung mobile phones), while improving power, performance and chip area.

Weâ€™re very excited about the increasing impact of AlphaChip internally and externally, and we look forward to continued work in this space to make custom higher performance, more efficient, and more capable chips dramatically easier to design and build.

An exciting update to our Open Buildings dataset.  It now features building presence over time (as well as building height information).  It does this by combining high resolution (50cm) but infrequent satellite images and low resolution (1000cm) but frequent (every 5 days).  It uses the high resolution imagery as a teacher to predict the higher resolution version from the more frequent lower resolution imagery.

This enables smooth analysis of buildings over time, as you can see in time lapse below of buildings and roads being constructed on the outskirts of Kumasi, Ghana.

Potential uses include:

Government agencies: Gain insights into urban growth patterns to inform planning decisions

Humanitarian organizations: Quickly assess the extent of built-up areas in disaster-stricken regions

Researchers: Track development trends, and study the impact of urbanization on the environment.

Read more on the blog post:

I'm really excited about this work.  As the earth warms, wildfires are becoming more common in many places on earth.  Early detection, before they burn out of control, is key to dramatically reducing their impact.  Current early detection satellites are only able to detect fires that are 2-3 acres in size.  With the FireSat constellation of 50 micro satellites for frequent coverage of every spot on Earth, and AI models trained on the sensor data, we'll be able to detect fires 1/400th that size (roughly 5x5 meters), enabling first responders to put out fires quickly.

The first satellite will launch next year, and the whole constellation (critical for detecting fires quickly) will be operational in the following few years.

Kudos to the whole team working on this at @GoogleResearch and to partners at @EarthFireAll, @MuonSpace and @MooreFound, and especially to my Google colleague Chris Van Arsdale, who has been working on this project for many years.

I am delighted that @TheOfficialACM has created the Luiz AndrÃ© Barroso Award to honor researchers from historically underrepresented communities who have made fundamental contributions to computer science

Nominations for this year are due Dec. 15, 2024:

text: @CJHandmer But I didn't forget!

Technology jobs, especially software-related ones, have been key drivers of economic growth and the building of important tools for society.  While there have been ups and downs in the job market for these skills in particular short term windows, if you look at the long term trends, there's lots of growth in demand and it's pretty clear we need more people with strong STEM and programming skills.  The mix of things that people might do in their jobs might change, so it's good to continuously learn new things.
(Opinions stated are my own and/or those of my daughter, not those of my company)

  "Sunnyvale starts serving Go2net"
  "AOL partnership"
  "Bogdan starts"
  "Google ski trip - Google stays up, Yahoo down"
  "Mar(ch) index war room"

text:
(2) Also in Building Zero, at some point we got fancy Japanese Toto toilets installed with infrared (?) remote controls mounted in each stall to control the features.

It turns out that reflective paint in the ceiling of a bathroom can cause infrared signals to bounce off the ceiling and control different toilets in other stalls at inopportune moments.

Soon thereafter, we moved to installing only one remotely controlled toilet per bathroom, and this approach has stayed true in (nearly?) every other Google building. ğŸ˜‚

Here's a couple:

(1) In the earliest days of Google, when we were all together in Building Zero, Lucas Pereira maintained an awesome "crayon chart" that showed the number of queries we got each day (grouped by whether they were on https://t.co/dEyZkxqHjJ or on various partner sites).  Each day the chart would get updated, and eventually got scaled down many times (10X, then 2X, then 5X,...).  People would annotate the chart with different events ("New index", "Sunnyvale starts serving Go2net", etc.) and early employees would annotate it with when they joined (the red arrow points to my faint pencil annotation on August 9 on the left hand image).

Pictures of most of the chart here (you have to imagine this thing stretched out as a 10 meter long sheet of paper on the wall).

More info here:
https://t.co/ykONxDDBTV

Before Google, I worked at Digital Equipment Corporation's Western Research Lab (two blocks from the sibling DEC Systems Research Center lab).  AltaVista spun out of a DEC WRL+DEC SRC collaboration, but when I arrived at DEC, some of my colleagues had built a graph of the web from an AltaVista crawl, and Monika Henzinger and I started to look at how to use the graph structure of the web to find related pages in the web.  Since compiler algorithms are often about graphs of various kinds, this wasn't as big a leap as it seems (web-based information retrieval was just starting to utilize the web graph structure in various ways, such as this work, PageRank, and other work around that time):

https://t.co/8T6FJcYUxM

@retornam Here's a hint: he's my academic uncle and I shared a three person office with him in the first location pictured above.  The office was so small all three of us couldn't roll our chairs back from our desks at the same time.

25 years ago today I officially started at a small search engine company, wedged into a tiny office space above what's now a T-Mobile store in downtown Palo Alto. Since then, I have had the incredible pleasure of working with awesome colleagues on software used by billions of people all over the world.

To all of my current and former colleagues, thank you for the collaborations, and I delight in what we have helped build together! ğŸ™

My first office:
Current office, my 16th different desk location at Google (more desk moves than 98.88% of Googlers):

There's a fun internal site that lets you see what percent of employees are newer than you at the company.  I'm almost at five 9s overall, but infinite 9s within our engineering group. ğŸ˜…

Thank you for indulging me in my moment of reflection!

Really excited to see us talk publicly about the progress on this work.    A few people in our awesome robotics team many years ago came to me and suggested that we should work on this problem (even though it would require buying some pricey higher speed robots) because it would push us to solve high speed controls and perception more than the other robotics problems we were working on.  It has been amazing to watch the progress over time!

Kudos to all the researchers involved, and you can read the paper at https://t.co/uhxc1I3RTs and see the thread below for some videos of the system in action.

An overview of @GoogleAI work showing one way that AI is helping reduce worldwide emissions, by better timing stop lights to reduce idling at intersections (and get people where they want to go faster) https://t.co/9AlRCk7EeE

It's really great to see the impact that TPUs have had and continue to have on Google's ability to do machine learning training and inference at scale, and to provide that same capability to @googlecloud customers via Cloud TPUs.  Here's a bit of backstory on how they came to be. https://t.co/hMgVDEh6Zp

text:
AI System Achieves Silver Medal-level score in IMO

The International Mathematical Olympiad (IMO) is the oldest, largest & most prestigious competition for young mathematicians.  Every year, countries send their top young mathematicians to take a 6 problem test spanning two days.  A few years ago, mathematical AI systems were lucky to be able to solve 1 in 100 of past IMO problems.  This year, @GoogleDeepMind built a system to tackle this year's IMO problems that combined two systems: AlphaGeometry 2, an improved version of our AlphaGeometry system, and AlphaProof, a new reinforcement-learning based system for formal mathematical reasoning.

The results?  During the week of the competition, this system was able to fully solve 4 of the 6 problems on this year's IMO exam, achieving a score of 28 (each problem is worth 7 points), placing it at the upper end of the IMO Silver Medal range (a level achieved by 58 of the 609 contestants in this year's IMO).
AlphaProof used a fine-tuned version of a Gemini model to automatically translate natural language problem statements into formal statements, creating a large library of formal problems of varying difficulty.  It then learned to solve IMO-like problems by proving or disproving millions of problems, covering a wide range of difficulties and mathematical topic areas over a period of weeks leading up to the competition.

â€œThe fact that the program can come up with a non-obvious construction like this is very impressive, and well beyond what I thought was state of the art."
â€” Prof Sir Timothy Gowers, IMO gold medalist and Fields Medal winner

Here is problem 4 of the 6, a geometry problem that AlphaGeometry solved in 19 seconds after receiving its formalization:

This represents a major advance in the capabilities of AI systems to correctly perform complex mathematical reasoning on par with the world's best young mathematicians.  Weâ€™re excited for a future in which mathematicians work with AI tools to explore hypotheses, try bold new approaches to solving long-standing problems and quickly complete time-consuming elements of proofs â€” and where AI systems like Gemini become more capable at math and broader reasoning.

See the blog post below for details:
https://t.co/5lYBWfhYEF

text: Small is beautiful!

Gemma 2 is now available available in 9B and 27B sizes (great for practical deployments) ğŸ‰

These open-source models offer best-in-class performance (often better than significantly larger models), run at incredible speed across different hardware and easily integrate with other AI tools.

Download the weights on @Kaggle and @HuggingFace, or access the models in Google AI Studio

Both sizes also do very well compared to other proprietary and open models on lmsys (although error bars are still largish due to limited votes so far):
See more on the blog:
https://t.co/0WrtElgh8e 

Tech report: https://t.co/RCREbHRIse

Congrats to all the people who have been working hard on this new release!

Nice thread on how to use the long context capabilities of Gemini 1.5 Pro to understand complex code bases.  Various approaches like:

"draw me an overall diagram of the major modules of the system"

"draw me neural net architectures for any sub models used"

"give me a list of files and summaries of what they do"

"list external components used"

"describe future roadmap of possible enhancements"

"what should I read to better understand the ideas behind the code"

"what are other open source repositories similar to this one"

etc.

text:
The updated report is now 153 pages, and has quite a few new results.  In the February report, I found the results on Kalamang translation for the Machine Translation from One Book benchmark quite exciting.  In this updated report, weâ€™ve extended this line of evaluation to test mixed-modal in-context learning capabilitiesâ€”by evaluating how well the model can learn to transcribe Kalamang speech from text and audio examples in context.  Both the 1.5 Pro and 1.5 Flash model show significant improvement as the number of in-context examples increases:

The models also show strong capability for in-context learning on several low resource language translation tasks, including English â†’ Bemba, English â†’ Kurdish, English â†’ Ewe, English â†’ Acholi, English â†’ Abkhaz, and English â†’ Navajo, with these graphs highlighting that as more example data is provided in context, the higher the quality of translation:

This sort of in-context learning of translation and speech recognition systems is quite exciting!  Check out the full report for more details.

text:
Gemini 1.5 Model Family: Technical Report updates now published

In the report we present the latest models of the Gemini family â€“ Gemini 1.5 Pro and Gemini 1.5 Flash, two highly compute-efficient multimodal models capable of recalling and reasoning over fine-grained information from millions of tokens of context, including multiple long documents and hours of video and audio.

Our latest report details notable improvements in Gemini 1.5 Pro within the last four months.

Our May release demonstrates significant improvement in math, coding, and multimodal benchmarks compared to our initial release in February.

Furthermore, the 1.5 Pro Model is now stronger than 1.0 Ultra.

The latest Gemini 1.5 Pro is now our most capable model for text and vision understanding tasks, surpassing 1.0 Ultra on 16 of 19 text benchmarks and 18 of 21 of the vision understanding benchmarks.  The table below highlights the improvement in average benchmark performance for different categories in 1.5 Pro since Feb, and also shows the strength of the model relative to the 1.0 Pro and 1.0 Ultra models. The 1.5 Flash model also compares very well against the 1.0 Pro and 1.0 Ultra models.

One clear example of this can be seen on MMLU

On MMLU we find that 1.5 Pro surpasses 1.0 Ultra in the regular 5-shot setting scoring 85.9% versus 83.7%. However with additional inference compute, via majority voting on top of multiple language model samples, we can get a performance of 91.7% versus Ultraâ€™s 90.0%, which extends the known performance ceiling of this task.

@OriolVinyalsML and I are very proud of the whole Gemini team, and itâ€™s fantastic to see this progress and to share these highlights from our Gemini Model Family.

Read the updated report here:  https://t.co/CTzTHND4nQ

Along with what to do about such issues: https://t.co/IBI9RVjDeM

I discussed the challenges of silent data corruption in ML training jobs, and how one faulty piece of hardware can infiltrate and affect the results of a large scale training jobs on thousands of chips. https://t.co/6vve9ORnh6
I gave an overview of some of the challenges and advances in our recent Gemini model training runs. https://t.co/3Q5I5Erdtb

I  discussed misinformation in the area of CO2 emissions from ML training, where one highly cited paper has a misleading and incorrect estimate that is off by 88X from the actual CO2 emissions of a one-time neural architecture search done by So et al., and is off by 118,000X from the actual emissions of training a model of the scale examined by the paper (2.5 kg instead of incorrect 284,000 kg estimate).

text: Among many other topics, here are a few things from the talk.  I gave an update on our use of reinforcement learning for ASIC chip placement and routing, showing how the adoption of this approach has been increasing from TPU generation to generation (due to further work on the system to improve performance on heavily congested blocks, for example), and also that the average wirelength reduction vs. human design has been increasing from generation to generation.

With our Gemini models and the Astra system on top of them, we're starting to see glimpses of systems that can understand the world around you and answer questions or have interesting discussions about things you're seeing.  Pretty cool!

There was a bit of confusing back and forth between myself and @ylecun recently, because in the tweet below, 'it' was referencing DistBelief, but @ylecun thought DistBelief referred to the ICML 2012 "cat detector" paper (https://t.co/8vgR7ntGls), not to the training system called DistBelief (which was used for the ICML 2012 paper but thousands of other things).  DistBelief was initially described in the NeurIPS 2012 paper (Large Scale Distributed Deep Networks, https://t.co/7xaB6LaWNy).  In some back-and-forth discussion, we've clarified that the "cat detector" paper did indeed use backprop (Yann thought it did not), and also that DistBelief supported training end-to-end convnet models starting in early 2012 (not later than the "cat detector" paper as Yann had thought, although the "cat detector" paper itself did not use convolutions because of its focus on evaluating biologically-plausible unsupervised learning: see (2) below).

Now that Yann clarified that it's the ICML 2012 paper which used DistBelief that he meant when he referred to "it" as a "dead end" (I presume Yann doesn't think the DistBelief system in the NeurIPS 2012 paper is a dead end?), let me say why I think the ICML 2012 paper was and is interesting, even if the particular unsupervised autoencoder technique described in the paper isn't widely used today.

(As an aside, I try not to refer to any research work as a "dead end", because I think much of how we progress as a field is by trying things, and that we all collectively learn a lot by seeing what specific ideas work, what general areas are interesting even if the specific ideas may need modifying, get inspired by multiple independent ideas that are combined in other work, etc.)

I think the ICML 2012 "cat detector" paper explored several things that together make it not a "dead end":

(1) It reported results on massively-scaled up neural networks (using the DistBelief software system that enabled this), training a neural net with 1B parameters (100X larger than the previously reported largest networks in the literature).  This alone showed many interesting properties (see (3) below).

(2) It evaluated a biologically-plausible approach for doing unsupervised learning on unlabeled images (random frames from YouTube videos), to explore what representations would be learned at high levels in the network when we significantly scaled up an autoencoder-based approach for learning representations from unlabeled data.  It did not use convolutions, because we wanted to use network architectures that were more biologically plausible (unshared weights, local receptive fields).  This neuroscience-inspired hypothesis is conveyed in the first part of the paper:

Indeed, interesting feature representations did emerge:

(3) In order to show that the unsupervised representations learned were useful for downstream supervised learning, we used supervised training on a neural network initialized with the pre-trained representations that were learned from (2), and compared that with a baseline trained in a purely supervised manner trained from random weights.  The results showed that (a) the unsupervised representations learned in a very large model gave significant improvements over the purely supervised approach (15.8% vs. 13.6% on ImageNet 22k), but also (b) that purely supervised learning of a very large model  gave major improvements over the prior state-of-the-art (13.6% vs. 9.3% prior SoTA).  To me, both (a) and (b) are interesting (and improvements of ~70% on state-of-the-art on ImageNet 22k seem interesting).

(4) The paper demonstrated how to use a combination of model parallelism (each model replica was distributed across 169 machines and also parallelized within each of these machines), as well as data parallelism (using multiple replicas of this setup) trained  with asynchronous SGD to train the model robustly and reliably, even in the presence of machine failures (we used 16,000 CPU cores on ~1000 machines).  I had explored and compared model parallel and data parallel training at a much smaller scale in my undergraduate thesis in 1990 (https://t.co/0JGKvGOaIy), but this is the first demonstration that I'm aware of for these two parallelism approaches to be put together in training a single system.  The NeurIPS 2012 paper on the DistBelief system explored a variety of different tradeoffs in this space, but the ICML 2012 paper was the first one that described this approach (almost as an aside in the paper, though).  Nearly all large-scale neural network training these days combines model parallel and data parallel training, and while a lot of large-scale training, I believe asynchronous training will be more and more important as we further scale neural networks.

To me, the lessons learned in (1), (2), (3), and (4) make this not a "dead end".  One major takeaway was that continued work on scaling up training of neural networks would lead to further major gains in accuracy across things like computer vision, speech recognition, and language processing.  This led to future systems like TPUs, TensorFlow, Pathways, PaLM, and Gemini.  Another was that using unsupervised (or self-supervised) methods can help give major boosts in accuracy and reduce the need for labeled data (known at the time, but demonstrated at large scale is still interesting).

Now, could we have done things differently?  Sure!

If we'd not been as interested in the biologically-plausible unsupervised learning of local receptive fields and non-shared weights, we could have used convolutions and likely gotten much more efficient learning and probably higher accuracy (it's not very efficient to learn the same kinds of low level filters at each spatial position in your network mostly independently).  However, as mentioned in (2), our goal wasn't to get really accurate ImageNet models, but rather to explore what kinds of high-level feature detectors emerged from purely biologically-plausible unsupervised learning. 

So, if this is what constitutes a "dead end", I'm delighted to be associated with this paper, along with my awesome co-authors @quocleix, @MarcRanzato, @rajatmonga, Matthieu Devin, Kai Chen,  @greg_corrado and @AndrewYNg .

@ylecun, sorry about the initial miscommunication, when your reference to "it" seemed to be discussing the NeurIPS 2012 paper/DistBelief system, rather than the ICML 2012 paper.  Because of that, I thought you were saying the DistBelief approach of scaled-up neural network training was a "dead end" and this made me a bit defensive, because I didn't believe it (and you just asserted it without any justification, which also didn't seem reasonable).  I'd be happy to hear in more detail which particular things in the ICML 2012 paper you feel are dead ends, or any response you have to the above points.

text: I'm still a bit surprised that you think the system (DistBelief) that first combined large scale model- and data- parallelism with backprop-based training of very large neural nets is a "dead end", given that nearly every large-scale model that is trained today combines these elements.

@ylecun @ChrSzegedy @xlcizor @deliprao @karpathy @AndrewYNg @woj_zaremba We supported shared weights from very early in DistBelief development, and we started adding support for various kinds of convolutions in March of 2012 (because convolutions are a very sensible idea for some things!), and you visited in July, I believe.
If you're at ICLR, you ode it to yourself to check this out.

@ylecun @quocleix @deliprao @karpathy @AndrewYNg DistBelief supported convolutions and end-to-end training with convolutions via backprop before the ICML 2012 paper appeared (even though that particular paper didn't use convolutions).

The name actually was "DistBelief" for a few reasons.  The first was a play on "disbelief", because many people didn't seem to believe the approach of large-scale distributed neural networks would work.  The second was because Deep Belief Networks was one of many algorithms we might want to explore.

text: DistBelief is the distributed training system used for that paper & 1000s of other things.  Your statement is equivalent to implementing an unsupervised algorithm in PyTorch, seeing modest results (like 70% relative improvement in SoTA on Imagenet 20k) & declaring PyTorch a dead end.

text: @alan_karthi The multimodal capabilities of the base Gemini models shine in evaluation of multimodal medical tasks in Med-Gemini, showing state-of-the-art results in 5 of the 8 benchmarks we examined. https://t.co/F7Z9pewpwK

Med-Gemini results are preferred over human expert results on long-form text-based tasks like medical summarization, doctor referral generation, and medical simplification (where the goal is to generate a plain language summary that can be understood by most readers without a university education, given a technical abstract from a medical systematic review)

On the NEJM CPC benchmark (an open-ended diagnosis task), the input is a text-based, challenging clinico-pathological case (CPC) report, and the output is a differential diagnosis list, comprising 10 potential diagnoses.  The Med-Gemini model does well on its own and improves further when augmented with a search capability (and although top-1 results are state of the art, the gap widens when looking at top-10 results).

text:
Great to see this new @GoogleResearch work on improved AI methods for flood forecasting published in @Nature today.

Floods are the most common natural disaster, and are responsible for roughly $50B in annual financial damages.  The flood-related disaster rate has more than doubled since the year 2000 partly due to climate change.  Nearly 1.5B people, making up 19% of the worldâ€™s population, are exposed to substantial risks from severe flood events.

Our earliest work in this area in India in 2018 relied on stream gauge measurements (essentially water depth measurements in different points in rivers and streams).  This worked well, but relied on having stream gauges and getting those measurements into an ML-based prediction system.

This work is able to make flood forecasts without the need for these stream gauge measurements, enabling us to do global flood forecasting, rather than only in a small number of countries where we were able to get stream gauge measurements.

Article: "Global prediction of extreme floods in ungauged watershedsâ€

The entire Gemini/Gemma team are really excited to see what people do with these models.  We think they are a great tool for a wide variety of use cases! https://t.co/5JLD2uzyJ2

From the blog, Gemma is available worldwide, starting today. Here are the key details to know:

o Weâ€™re releasing model weights in two sizes: Gemma 2B and Gemma 7B. Each size is released with pre-trained and instruction-tuned variants.

o Weâ€™re providing toolchains for inference and supervised fine-tuning (SFT) across all major frameworks: JAX, PyTorch, and TensorFlow through native Keras 3.0.

o Ready-to-use Colab and Kaggle notebooks, alongside integration with popular tools such as Hugging Face, MaxText, NVIDIA NeMo and TensorRT-LLM, make it easy to get started with Gemma.

o Pre-trained and instruction-tuned Gemma models can run on your laptop, workstation, or Google Cloud with easy deployment on Vertex AI and Google Kubernetes Engine (GKE).

o Optimization across multiple AI hardware platforms ensures industry-leading performance, including NVIDIA GPUs and Google Cloud TPUs.

o Terms of use permit responsible commercial usage and distribution for all organizations, regardless of size.

text:
We are very excited to be able to share our work on this next iteration of Gemini.  We canâ€™t wait to see how people creatively use the long context capabilities to do all kinds of things that previously were not possible.  How would you use these capabilities?

And now, back to some other things weâ€™re ultra excited about!

Seeing farther

Sometimes when you're looking at something, you're a bit too close to it to see important aspects.

The long context work enables us to all see a bit further.

Mixture of Experts

Gemini 1.5 Pro uses a mixture-of-expert (MoE) architecture, building on a long line of Google research efforts on sparse models:

2017: Shazeer et al.. Outrageously large neural networks: The sparsely-gated mixture-of-experts layer.  ICLR 2017. https://t.co/qE9mkuGp5s
2020: Lepikhin et al., GShard: Scaling giant models with conditional computation and automatic sharding. ICLR 2020. https://t.co/hVgluKSGxy
2021: Carlos Riquelme et al., Scaling vision with sparse mixture of experts, NeurIPS 2021. https://t.co/xF5sATEiMj
2021: Fedus et al., Switch transformers: Scaling to trillion parameter models with simple and efficient sparsity. JMLR 2022.  https://t.co/m9Jac2UfR8
Clark et al., Unified scaling laws for routed language models, ICML 2022. https://t.co/4C95UwiH37
2022: Zoph et al., Designing effective sparse expert models. https://t.co/VWTxyVeJ4X

text:
Basic Capabilities

Weâ€™ve been able to add the long context ability without sacrificing on other capabilities.  Although it required a small fraction of the training time of the Gemini 1.0 Ultra model, the 1.5 Pro model exceeds the performance of the 1.0 Ultra model on 17 of 31 benchmarks.  Compared to the 1.0 Pro model, the 1.5 Pro model exceeds its performance on 27 of 31 benchmarks.

Tables 8 and 10 in the tech report have lots more details.

text:
Multineedle in haystack test

We also created a generalized version of the needle in a haystack test, where the model must retrieve 100 different needles hidden in the context window.  For this, we see that Gemini 1.5 Proâ€™s performance is above that of GPT-4 Turbo at small context lengths and remains relatively steady across the entire 1M context window, while the GPT-4 Turbo model drops off more quickly (and cannot go past 128k tokens).

text:
Kalamang Translation

One of the most exciting examples in the report involves translation of Kalamang.  Kalamang is a language spoken by fewer than 200 speakers in western New Guinea in the east of Indonesian Papua (https://t.co/2qAvCoQTLR).  Kalamang has almost no online presence.  Machine Translation from One Book (MTOB: https://t.co/dUjJxTZ6Cr) is a recently introduced benchmark evaluating the ability of a learning system to learn to translate Kalamang from just a single book.

Eline Visser (https://t.co/382qNz6vx0) wrote a 573 page book â€œA Grammar of Kalamangâ€ (https://t.co/xXRW0vKwJc). 
 Thank you, Eline!  The text of this book is used in the MTOB benchmark.  With this book and a simple bilingual wordlist (dictionary) provided in context, Gemini 1.5 Pro can learn to translate from English to/from Kalamang.  Without the Kalamang materials in context, the 1.5 Pro model produces almost random translations.  However, with the materials in the context window, Gemini Pro 1.5 is able to use in-context learning about Kalamang, and we find that the quality of its translations is comparable to that of a person who has learned from the same materials.  With a ChrF of 58.3 for English->Kalamang translation, Gemini Pro 1.5 improves substantially over the best model score of 45.8 ChrF and also slightly exceeds the human baseline of 57.0 ChrF reported in the MTOB paper (https://t.co/dUjJxTZ6Cr).

The possibilities for significantly improving translation for very low resource languages are quite exciting!

text:
Reasoning about long text documents

The model also shines at analyzing long, complex text documents, like Victor Hugoâ€™s five volume novel â€œLes MisÃ©rablesâ€ (1382 pages, 732k tokens).  The multimodal capabilities are demonstrated by coarsely sketching a scene and saying â€œLook at the event in this drawing.  What page is this on?â€

Analyzing and reasoning about videos

Analyzing videos is another great capability brought by the fact that Gemini models are naturally multimodal, and this becomes even more compelling with long contexts.  Consider Gemini 1.5 Proâ€™s ability to analyze movies, like Buster Keatonâ€™s silent 45 minute â€œSherlock Jr.â€ movie.  Using one frame per second, we turn this into an input context of 684k tokens.  The model can then answer fairly complex questions about the video content, such as:

â€œTell me some key information from the piece of paper that is removed from the personâ€™s pocket, and the timecode of that moment.â€

Or, a very cursory line drawing of something that happened, combined with â€œWhat is the timecode when this happens?â€

You can see this interaction here:
https://t.co/adyMgDYHoK

text:
Navigating large and unfamiliar code bases

As another code-related example, imagine youâ€™re unfamiliar with a large codebase and want the model to help you understand the code or find where particular functionality is implemented.  In this example the model is able to ingest the entire 116 file JAX code base (746k tokens) and help the user identify the specific spot in the code that implements the backwards pass for autodifferentiation.

Itâ€™s easy to see how the long context capabilities can be invaluable when diving in to an unfamiliar code base or working with one that you use every day.  Many Gemini team members have been finding it very useful to use Gemini 1.5 Proâ€™s long context capabilities on our Gemini code base.

text:
Gemini 1.5 Pro - A highly capable multimodal model with a 10M token context length

Today we are releasing the first demonstrations of the capabilities of the Gemini 1.5 series, with the Gemini 1.5 Pro model.  One of the key differentiators of this model is its incredibly long context capabilities, supporting millions of tokens of multimodal input.  The multimodal capabilities of the model means you can interact in sophisticated ways with entire books, very long document collections, codebases of hundreds of thousands of lines across hundreds of files, full movies, entire podcast series, and more.

Gemini 1.5 was built by an amazing team of people from @GoogleDeepMind, @GoogleResearch, and elsewhere at @Google. @OriolVinyals (my co-technical lead for the project) and I are incredibly proud of the whole team, and weâ€™re so excited to be sharing this work and what long context and in-context learning can mean for you today!

Thereâ€™s lots of material about this, some of which are linked to below.

Main blog post:
https://t.co/QAsDKXBdao

Technical report:
â€œGemini 1.5: Unlocking multimodal understanding across millions of tokens of contextâ€
https://t.co/CTzTHNDCdo

Videos of interactions with the model that highlight its long context abilities:
Understanding the three.js codebase: https://t.co/yq7d6OSD6c
Analyzing a 45 minute Buster Keaton movie: https://t.co/adyMgDYHoK
Apollo 11 transcript interaction: https://t.co/Pqvq3Eac1R

Starting today, weâ€™re offering a limited preview of 1.5 Pro to developers and enterprise customers via AI Studio and Vertex AI. Read more about this on these blogs:
Google for Developers blog:
https://t.co/x73Vun0kVS
Google Cloud blog: 
https://t.co/OlaTW6PYGn

Weâ€™ll also introduce 1.5 Pro with a standard 128,000 token context window when the model is ready for a wider release. Coming soon, we plan to introduce pricing tiers that start at the standard 128,000 context window and scale up to 1 million tokens, as we improve the model.

Early testers can try the 1 million token context window at no cost during the testing period.  Weâ€™re excited to see what developerâ€™s creativity unlocks with a very long context window.

Let me walk you through the capabilities of the model and what Iâ€™m excited about!

@_akhaliq We also focused a fair bit on lookup performance since this was used as the production language model serving system for Google Translate for many years.  As described in the paper, the system could support ~4.3M lookups/sec from a single client, & often had dozens clients/model.
@RajAnand Sounds like the Costa's clear, then?

Thanks!

The infini-gram aspect of your work is cool and definitely different.  I was just going by what seemed to be the raw number of tokens computed over to form the data structure.

(Our 300B number was the number of actual counts stored in our data structure: you could look up longer n-grams and it would fall back to whatever was present).

Nice work!

Indeed, training on purely text data is not going to be enough.  Training on audio language data is likely to be better (e.g. your example of languages that use clicks), and making sure that the data truly represents the way that people use a language is critical to represent that community's culture.

@lamechthinkbig (Your point of this being complex to get right is absolutely correct, though, and rolling it out to real products is also more involved than just showing the approach in a research setting!)

There is evidence that jointly training on many languages improves the translation quality of all languages (compared with training translation models on just a single language pair).  For example, see this figure from https://t.co/32LciHXcsr which shows low resource languages improving the most from this approach.

(adapted from https://t.co/hVgluKSGxy)

Improving speech & text understanding in 1,000 languages will make computing more effective for billions of people, and making information more accessible.  Machine learning, and learning across different languages, can advance the capabilities of these systems for all.
@isosteph Sometimes we struggle, but other times we flounder.  The best things come when you find a co-flounder.
@robleathern I didn't work directly in that area, but capable language models are clearly useful in all kinds of areas like that.

Very sad to hear. ğŸ˜¥ Niklaus Wirth made many enormous contributions to the field of computing.  Pascal was the first language I used seriously (initially on the UCSD p-System and later via Turbo Pascal), and I got my hands on this great book that he wrote when I was in middle school.  Later, I loved using Modula-2 for some things (and his indirect influence on Modula-3 was strong).

I also love the anecdote when asked about how to pronounce his name:

"Whereas Europeans generally pronounce my name the right way ('Ni-klows Wirt'), Americans invariably mangle it into 'Nick-les Worth'. This is to say that Europeans call me by name, but Americans call me by value.

Niklaus Wirth"
